oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ASSESSING THE BENEFITS OF BEACHES IN FLOOD RISK REDUCTION
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Toimil, Alexandra
Losada, Iñigo
Álvarez-Cuesta, Moisés
Cozannet, Gonéri Le
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Beaches and other ecosystems such as dune systems, wetlands, mangroves, and coral reefs provide protection services against flooding that can be as valuable as hard engineered structures. Beaches have the particularity of being more dynamic than coral reefs and mangroves as they adapt quickly to changes in coastal dynamics. Therefore, the protection benefits they provide are strongly linked to this dynamism and their changing shape at different scales. This brings additional complexity to coastal flood modelling as it can be shaped by shoreline changes that are often neglected (Toimil et al., 2023a). In this work, we present a new approach to quantify the benefits of beaches in flood risk reduction considering the dynamic interaction of storm and sea-level rise erosion, with and coastal flooding (Toimil et al., 2023b). We apply the proposed approach in Narrabeen-Collaroy (Australia) considering uncertainty in the climate part of the shared socioeconomic pathways, sea-level rise projections, and initial beach conditions (uneroded and eroded due to a previous back-to-back storm without time to recover).
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; management.186
